revisions.rev:
[[Image:US-O10 insignia.svg|300px|right|thumb|A US general's rank insignia<ref>Note: This rank insignia is not worn by all NATO officers.</ref>]] {{Main|Ranks and insignia of NATO armies officers|Ranks and insignia of NATO Air Forces Officers|Ranks and insignia of NATO Navies Officers}}
'''Four-star rank''' is a term used to describe a very senior commander in many of the armed services holding a rank described by the [[Ranks and insignia of NATO|NATO OF-9 code]]. The term is also used by some armed forces which are not NATO members. Typically, four-star officers would hold the rank of [[admiral]], [[general]] or in the case of those air forces with a separate rank structure, [[air chief marshal]].
==Australia== [[Image:RAN-Admiral-shoulder.gif|thumb|right|50px|Australian admiral's shoulder board]] [[File:Cdn Frces Admiral Shoulder Board.gif|thumb|Canadian Admiral's shoulder board]] [[File:Fali Homi Major.JPG|thumb|right|100px|Indian Air Chief Marshal [[Fali Homi Major]] wearing four-star insignia]] [[File:MAS10.jpg|thumb|right|100px|Pakistan Air Chief Marhsal [[Anwar Shamim]] with 4 stars visible on his head-dress]]
*[[Admiral (Australia)|Admiral]] ([[Royal Australian Navy]] four-star rank) *[[General (Australia)|General]] ([[Australian Army]] four-star rank) *[[Air Chief Marshal (Australia)|Air chief marshal]] ([[Royal Australian Air Force]] four-star rank)
The four-star rank is reserved in Australia for the [[Chief of the Defence Force (Australia)|Chief of the Defence Force]], the highest position in peace time.
In times of major conflict, the highest ranks are the [[five-star rank]]s: [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Australian Navy)|admiral of the fleet]], [[Field Marshal (Australia)|field marshal]], and [[Marshal of the Air Force|marshal of the Royal Australian Air Force]].
==Canada== *[[Admiral (Canada)|Admiral]] ([[Canadian Forces]] officers authorized to wear naval uniform four-star-equivalent rank) *[[General (Canada)|General/gÃ©nÃ©ral]] ([[Canadian Forces]] officers authorized to wear army and air force uniform four-star-equivalent rank)
Four maple leaves appear with St. Edward's crown and crossed sabre and baton on epaulettes and shoulder boards. In Canada and when referring to Canadian officers, it is sometimes referred to as the "4-leaf" rank, rather than "four-star".{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}}<!-- I doubt it! Supporting evidence please!!! -->
This is the highest rank that is defined in the [[Canadian Forces]] under the current [[National Defence Act]] Schedule.<ref>Canada - Department of Justice "[http://laws.justice.gc.ca/eng/N-5/page-6.html#anchorsc:1/ Laws of Canada: National Defence Act, Schedule I]"</ref> Usually, only one officer carries the rank of full Admiral/ General at any one time: The [[Chief of the Defence Staff (Canada)|Chief of the Defence Staff]]. In exceptional circumstances, from time-to-time, the minister may authorize additional officers at that level, for instance, Canadian officers in the position of [[Chairman of the NATO Military Committee]] are usually former Chiefs of the Defence Staff seconded to NATO for that duty.
The [[Monarchy of Canada|Head of State]] holds the position of Commander-in-Chief of the [[Canadian Forces]], bearing no rank.<ref>Canada - Department of Justice "[http://laws.justice.gc.ca/eng/Const/2.html/ Constitution Act, 1867, Part III, Section 9, Executive Power.]"</ref> Likewise, the [[Minister of National Defence (Canada)|Minister of National Defence]], since they are not a member of the Canadian Forces, nor in the chain-of-command, also bears no rank. [[Prince Philip]] holds the four-star rank of admiral in the [[Royal Canadian Navy]] in an honorary capacity.
Before unification in 1968, the rank of [[air chief marshal]] was the four-star equivalent for the [[Royal Canadian Air Force]].
==India== *[[Director of Intelligence Bureau (India)|Director]] ([[Intelligence Bureau (India)|Intelligence Bureau]] four-star rank) *[[Chief of Army Staff of the Indian Army|General]] ([[Indian Army]] four-star rank) *[[Chief of Air Staff (India)|Air chief marshal]] ([[Indian Air Force]] four-star rank) *[[Chief of Naval Staff of the Indian Navy|Admiral]] ([[Indian Navy]] four-star rank)
==Pakistan== *[[General]] ([[Pakistan Army]] four-star rank) *[[Air chief marshal]] ([[Pakistan Air Force]] four-star rank) *[[Admiral]] ([[Pakistan Navy]] four-star rank)
==United Kingdom== *[[Admiral (United Kingdom)|Admiral]] ([[Royal Navy]] four-star rank) *[[General (United Kingdom)|General]] ([[British Army]] and [[Royal Marines]] four-star rank)<ref>http://www.army.mod.uk/structure/23155.aspx</ref> *[[Air chief marshal]] ([[Royal Air Force]] four-star rank)<ref>[http://www.rafweb.org/Glossary.htm RAF Glossary], "Air of Authority - A History of RAF Organisation", rafweb.org</ref> {{See also|List of Royal Air Force air chief marshals}}
==United States== *[[Admiral (United States)|Admiral]] ([[United States Navy]], [[USCG|Coast Guard]], [[NOAA Corps]], and [[Public Health Service Commissioned Corps]] four-star rank) *[[General (United States)|General]] ([[United States Army]], [[USAF|Air Force]], and [[USMC|Marine Corps]] four-star rank) See also: *[[List of active duty United States four-star officers]] *[[List of United States Navy four-star admirals]] *[[List of United States Public Health Service Commissioned Corps four-star admirals]] *[[List of United States Army four-star generals]] *[[List of United States Air Force four-star generals]] *[[List of United States Marine Corps four-star generals]]
